trans-unit.source: How to use Table storage from Node.js | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Table storage from Node.js | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the table storage service in Azure. Code samples are written using the Node.js API.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the table storage service in Azure. Code samples are written using the Node.js API.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Table service in a Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Table service in a Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: The code examples in this topic assume you already have a Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: The code examples in this topic assume you already have a Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on creating a Node.js application in Azure, see any of these topics:
trans-unit.target: For instructions on creating a Node.js application in Azure, see any of these topics:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Build and deploy a Node.js website to Azure[create and deploy a node.js application to an azure web site]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Build and deploy a Node.js website to Azure[create and deploy a node.js application to an azure web site]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Build and deploy a Node.js website to Azure using WebMatrix[web site with webmatrix]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Build and deploy a Node.js website to Azure using WebMatrix[web site with webmatrix]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Build and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Cloud Service[node.js cloud service]</linkText><title></title> (using Windows PowerShell)
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Build and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Cloud Service[node.js cloud service]</linkText><title></title> (using Windows PowerShell)

trans-unit.source: To use Azure storage, you need the Azure Storage SDK for Node.js, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure storage, you need the Azure Storage SDK for Node.js, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.

trans-unit.source: Use a command-line interface such as PowerShell (Windows) Terminal (Mac) or Bash (Unix), and navigate to the folder where you created your application.
trans-unit.target: Use a command-line interface such as PowerShell (Windows) Terminal (Mac) or Bash (Unix), and navigate to the folder where you created your application.

trans-unit.source: Type npm install azure-storage in the command window.
trans-unit.target: Type npm install azure-storage in the command window.

trans-unit.source: Output from the command is similar to the following example.
trans-unit.target: Output from the command is similar to the following example.

trans-unit.source: You can manually run the ls command to verify that a node\_modules folder was created.
trans-unit.target: You can manually run the ls command to verify that a node\_modules folder was created.

trans-unit.source: Inside that folder you will find the azure-storage package, which contains the libraries you need to access storage.
trans-unit.target: Inside that folder you will find the azure-storage package, which contains the libraries you need to access storage.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the top of the server.js file in your application:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the top of the server.js file in your application:

trans-unit.source: The azure module will read the environment variables AZURE\STORAGE\ACCOUNT and AZURE\STORAGE\ACCESS\KEY, or AZURE\STORAGE\CONNECTION\STRING for information required to connect to your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: The azure module will read the environment variables AZURE\STORAGE\ACCOUNT and AZURE\STORAGE\ACCESS\KEY, or AZURE\STORAGE\CONNECTION\STRING for information required to connect to your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the account information when calling TableService.
trans-unit.target: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the account information when calling TableService.

trans-unit.source: For an example of setting the environment variables in the management portal for an Azure Website, see [Node.js Web Application with Storage]
trans-unit.target: For an example of setting the environment variables in the management portal for an Azure Website, see [Node.js Web Application with Storage]

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a TableService object and uses it to create a new table.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a TableService object and uses it to create a new table.

trans-unit.source: Add the following near the top of server.js.
trans-unit.target: Add the following near the top of server.js.

trans-unit.source: The call to createTableIfNotExists will create a new table with the specified name if it does not already exist.
trans-unit.target: The call to createTableIfNotExists will create a new table with the specified name if it does not already exist.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a new table named 'mytable' if it does not already exist:
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a new table named 'mytable' if it does not already exist:

trans-unit.source: The result will be true if a new table is created, and false if the table already exists.
trans-unit.target: The result will be true if a new table is created, and false if the table already exists.

trans-unit.source: response will contain information about the request.
trans-unit.target: response will contain information about the request.

trans-unit.source: Optional filtering operations can be applied to operations performed using TableService.
trans-unit.target: Optional filtering operations can be applied to operations performed using TableService.

trans-unit.source: Filtering operations can include logging, automatically retrying, etc. Filters are objects that implement a method with the signature:
trans-unit.target: Filtering operations can include logging, automatically retrying, etc. Filters are objects that implement a method with the signature:

trans-unit.source: After doing its preprocessing on the request options, the method needs to call "next" passing a callback with the following signature:
trans-unit.target: After doing its preprocessing on the request options, the method needs to call "next" passing a callback with the following signature:

trans-unit.source: In this callback, and after processing the returnObject (the response from the request to the server), the callback needs to either invoke next if it exists to continue processing other filters or simply invoke finalCallback otherwise to end up the service invocation.
trans-unit.target: In this callback, and after processing the returnObject (the response from the request to the server), the callback needs to either invoke next if it exists to continue processing other filters or simply invoke finalCallback otherwise to end up the service invocation.

trans-unit.source: Two filters that implement retry logic are included with the Azure SDK for Node.js, ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter and LinearRetryPolicyFilter.
trans-unit.target: Two filters that implement retry logic are included with the Azure SDK for Node.js, ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter and LinearRetryPolicyFilter.

trans-unit.source: The following creates a TableService object that uses the ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter:
trans-unit.target: The following creates a TableService object that uses the ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter:

trans-unit.source: To add an entity, first create an object that defines your entity properties.
trans-unit.target: To add an entity, first create an object that defines your entity properties.

trans-unit.source: All entities must contain a PartitionKey and RowKey, which are unique identifiers for the entity.
trans-unit.target: All entities must contain a PartitionKey and RowKey, which are unique identifiers for the entity.

trans-unit.source: PartitionKey - Determines the partition that the entity is stored in.
trans-unit.target: PartitionKey - Determines the partition that the entity is stored in.

trans-unit.source: RowKey - Uniquely identifies the entity within the partition.
trans-unit.target: RowKey - Uniquely identifies the entity within the partition.

trans-unit.source: Both PartitionKey and RowKey must be string values.
trans-unit.target: Both PartitionKey and RowKey must be string values.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Understanding the Table Service data model</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Understanding the Table Service data model</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The following is an example of defining an entity.
trans-unit.target: The following is an example of defining an entity.

trans-unit.source: Note that dueDate is defined as a type of Edm.DateTime.
trans-unit.target: Note that dueDate is defined as a type of Edm.DateTime.

trans-unit.source: Specifying the type is optional, and types will be inferred if not specified.
trans-unit.target: Specifying the type is optional, and types will be inferred if not specified.

trans-unit.source: There is also a Timestamp field for each record, which is set by Azure when an entity is inserted or updated.
trans-unit.target: There is also a Timestamp field for each record, which is set by Azure when an entity is inserted or updated.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the entityGenerator to create entities.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the entityGenerator to create entities.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates the same task entity using the entityGenerator.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates the same task entity using the entityGenerator.

trans-unit.source: To add an entity to your table, pass the entity object to the insertEntity method.
trans-unit.target: To add an entity to your table, pass the entity object to the insertEntity method.

trans-unit.source: If the operation is successful, result will contain the ETag of the inserted record and response will contain information about the operation.
trans-unit.target: If the operation is successful, result will contain the ETag of the inserted record and response will contain information about the operation.

trans-unit.source: Example response:
trans-unit.target: Example response:

trans-unit.source: By default, insertEntity does not return the inserted entity as part of the response information.
trans-unit.target: By default, insertEntity does not return the inserted entity as part of the response information.

trans-unit.source: If you plan on performing other operations on this entity, or wish to cache the information, it can be useful to have it returned as part of the result.
trans-unit.target: If you plan on performing other operations on this entity, or wish to cache the information, it can be useful to have it returned as part of the result.

trans-unit.source: You can do this by enabling echoContent as follows:
trans-unit.target: You can do this by enabling echoContent as follows:

trans-unit.source: tableSvc.insertEntity('mytable', task, {echoContent: true}, function (error, result, response) {...}
trans-unit.target: tableSvc.insertEntity('mytable', task, {echoContent: true}, function (error, result, response) {...}

trans-unit.source: There are multiple methods available to update an existing entity:
trans-unit.target: There are multiple methods available to update an existing entity:

trans-unit.source: updateEntity - Updates an existing entity by replacing it.
trans-unit.target: updateEntity - Updates an existing entity by replacing it.

trans-unit.source: mergeEntity - Updates an existing entity by merging new property values into the existing entity.
trans-unit.target: mergeEntity - Updates an existing entity by merging new property values into the existing entity.

trans-unit.source: insertOrReplaceEntity - Updates an existing entity by replacing it.
trans-unit.target: insertOrReplaceEntity - Updates an existing entity by replacing it.

trans-unit.source: If no entity exists, a new one will be inserted.
trans-unit.target: If no entity exists, a new one will be inserted.

trans-unit.source: insertOrMergeEntity - Updates an existing entity by merging new property values into the existing.
trans-unit.target: insertOrMergeEntity - Updates an existing entity by merging new property values into the existing.

trans-unit.source: If no entity exists, a new one will be inserted.
trans-unit.target: If no entity exists, a new one will be inserted.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates updating an entity using updateEntity:
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates updating an entity using updateEntity:

trans-unit.source: By default, updating an entity does not check to see if the data being updated has previously been modified by another process.
trans-unit.target: By default, updating an entity does not check to see if the data being updated has previously been modified by another process.

trans-unit.source: To support concurrent updates:
trans-unit.target: To support concurrent updates:

trans-unit.source: Get the ETag of the object being updated.
trans-unit.target: Get the ETag of the object being updated.

trans-unit.source: This is returned as part of the response for any entity related operation and can be retrieved through response['.metadata'].etag.
trans-unit.target: This is returned as part of the response for any entity related operation and can be retrieved through response['.metadata'].etag.

trans-unit.source: When performing an update operation on an entity, add the ETag information previously retrieved to the new entity.
trans-unit.target: When performing an update operation on an entity, add the ETag information previously retrieved to the new entity.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: entity2['.metadata'].etag = currentEtag;
trans-unit.target: entity2['.metadata'].etag = currentEtag;

trans-unit.source: Perform the update operation.
trans-unit.target: Perform the update operation.

trans-unit.source: If the entity has been modified since you retrieved the ETag value, such as another instance of your application, an error will be returned stating that the update condition specified in the request was not satisfied.
trans-unit.target: If the entity has been modified since you retrieved the ETag value, such as another instance of your application, an error will be returned stating that the update condition specified in the request was not satisfied.

trans-unit.source: With updateEntity and mergeEntity, if the entity that is being updated doesn't exist then the update operation will fail.
trans-unit.target: With updateEntity and mergeEntity, if the entity that is being updated doesn't exist then the update operation will fail.

trans-unit.source: Therefore if you wish to store an entity regardless of whether it already exists, use insertOrReplaceEntity or insertOrMergeEntity.
trans-unit.target: Therefore if you wish to store an entity regardless of whether it already exists, use insertOrReplaceEntity or insertOrMergeEntity.

trans-unit.source: The result for successful update operations will contain the Etag of the updated entity.
trans-unit.target: The result for successful update operations will contain the Etag of the updated entity.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes it makes sense to submit multiple operations together in a batch to ensure atomic processing by the server.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes it makes sense to submit multiple operations together in a batch to ensure atomic processing by the server.

trans-unit.source: To accomplish that, use the TableBatch class to create a batch, and then use the executeBatch method of TableService to perform the batched operations.
trans-unit.target: To accomplish that, use the TableBatch class to create a batch, and then use the executeBatch method of TableService to perform the batched operations.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates submitting two entities in a batch:
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates submitting two entities in a batch:

trans-unit.source: For successful batch operations, result will contain information for each operation in the batch.
trans-unit.target: For successful batch operations, result will contain information for each operation in the batch.

trans-unit.source: Operations added to a batch can be inspected by viewing the operations property.
trans-unit.target: Operations added to a batch can be inspected by viewing the operations property.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the following methods to work with operations.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the following methods to work with operations.

trans-unit.source: clear - clears all operations from a batch.
trans-unit.target: clear - clears all operations from a batch.

trans-unit.source: getOperations - gets an operation from the batch.
trans-unit.target: getOperations - gets an operation from the batch.

trans-unit.source: hasOperations - returns true if the batch contains operations.
trans-unit.target: hasOperations - returns true if the batch contains operations.

trans-unit.source: removeOperations - removes an operation.
trans-unit.target: removeOperations - removes an operation.

trans-unit.source: size - returns the number of operations in the batch.
trans-unit.target: size - returns the number of operations in the batch.

trans-unit.source: To return a specific entity based on the PartitionKey and RowKey, use the retrieveEntity method.
trans-unit.target: To return a specific entity based on the PartitionKey and RowKey, use the retrieveEntity method.

trans-unit.source: Once this operation completes, result will contain the entity.
trans-unit.target: Once this operation completes, result will contain the entity.

trans-unit.source: To query a table, use the TableQuery object to build up a query expression using the following clauses:
trans-unit.target: To query a table, use the TableQuery object to build up a query expression using the following clauses:

trans-unit.source: select - The fields to be returned from the query.
trans-unit.target: select - The fields to be returned from the query.

trans-unit.source: where - The where clause.
trans-unit.target: where - The where clause.

trans-unit.source: and - An and where condition.
trans-unit.target: and - An and where condition.

trans-unit.source: or - An or where condition.
trans-unit.target: or - An or where condition.

trans-unit.source: top - The number of items to fetch.
trans-unit.target: top - The number of items to fetch.

trans-unit.source: The following example builds a query that will return the top 5 items with a PartitionKey of 'hometasks'.
trans-unit.target: The following example builds a query that will return the top 5 items with a PartitionKey of 'hometasks'.

trans-unit.source: Since select is not used, all fields will be returned.
trans-unit.target: Since select is not used, all fields will be returned.

trans-unit.source: To perform the query against a table, use queryEntities.
trans-unit.target: To perform the query against a table, use queryEntities.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses this query to return entities from 'mytable'.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses this query to return entities from 'mytable'.

trans-unit.source: If successful, result.entries will contain an array of entities that match the query.
trans-unit.target: If successful, result.entries will contain an array of entities that match the query.

trans-unit.source: If the query was unable to return all entities, result.continuationToken will be non-null and can be used as the third parameter of queryEntities to retrieve more results.
trans-unit.target: If the query was unable to return all entities, result.continuationToken will be non-null and can be used as the third parameter of queryEntities to retrieve more results.

trans-unit.source: For the initial query, use null for the third parameter.
trans-unit.target: For the initial query, use null for the third parameter.

trans-unit.source: A query to a table can retrieve just a few fields from an entity.
trans-unit.target: A query to a table can retrieve just a few fields from an entity.

trans-unit.source: This reduces bandwidth and can improve query performance, especially for large entities.
trans-unit.target: This reduces bandwidth and can improve query performance, especially for large entities.

trans-unit.source: Use the select clause and pass the names of the fields to be returned.
trans-unit.target: Use the select clause and pass the names of the fields to be returned.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following query will only return the description and dueDate fields.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following query will only return the description and dueDate fields.

trans-unit.source: You can delete an entity using its partition and row keys.
trans-unit.target: You can delete an entity using its partition and row keys.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the task1 object contains the RowKey and PartitionKey values of the entity to be deleted.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the task1 object contains the RowKey and PartitionKey values of the entity to be deleted.

trans-unit.source: Then the object is passed to the deleteEntity method.
trans-unit.target: Then the object is passed to the deleteEntity method.

trans-unit.source: Consider using ETags when deleting items, to ensure that the item hasn't been modified by another process.
trans-unit.target: Consider using ETags when deleting items, to ensure that the item hasn't been modified by another process.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Update an Entity</linkText><title></title> for information in using ETags.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Update an Entity</linkText><title></title> for information in using ETags.

trans-unit.source: The following code deletes a table from a storage account.
trans-unit.target: The following code deletes a table from a storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you are uncertain whether the table exists, use deleteTableIfExists.
trans-unit.target: If you are uncertain whether the table exists, use deleteTableIfExists.

trans-unit.source: When you are querying tables for large amounts of results, look for continuation tokens.
trans-unit.target: When you are querying tables for large amounts of results, look for continuation tokens.

trans-unit.source: There may be large amounts of data available for your query that you might not realize if you do not build to recognize when a continuation token is present.
trans-unit.target: There may be large amounts of data available for your query that you might not realize if you do not build to recognize when a continuation token is present.

trans-unit.source: The results object returned when querying entities sets a continuationToken property when such a token is present.
trans-unit.target: The results object returned when querying entities sets a continuationToken property when such a token is present.

trans-unit.source: You can then use this when performing a query to continue to move across the partition and table entities.
trans-unit.target: You can then use this when performing a query to continue to move across the partition and table entities.

trans-unit.source: When querying, a continuationToken parameter may be provided between the query object instance and the callback function:
trans-unit.target: When querying, a continuationToken parameter may be provided between the query object instance and the callback function:

trans-unit.source: If you inspect the continuationToken object, you will find properties such as nextPartitionKey, nextRowKey and targetLocation which can be used to iterate through all the results.
trans-unit.target: If you inspect the continuationToken object, you will find properties such as nextPartitionKey, nextRowKey and targetLocation which can be used to iterate through all the results.

trans-unit.source: There is also a continuation sample within the Azure Storage Node.js repo on GitHub, look for examples/samples/continuationsample.js.
trans-unit.target: There is also a continuation sample within the Azure Storage Node.js repo on GitHub, look for examples/samples/continuationsample.js.

trans-unit.source: Shared Access Signatures (SAS) are a secure way to provide granular access to tables without providing your storage account name or keys.
trans-unit.target: Shared Access Signatures (SAS) are a secure way to provide granular access to tables without providing your storage account name or keys.

trans-unit.source: SAS are often used to provide limited access to your data, such as allowing a mobile app to query records.
trans-unit.target: SAS are often used to provide limited access to your data, such as allowing a mobile app to query records.

trans-unit.source: A trusted application such as a cloud-based service generates a SAS using the generateSharedAccessSignature of the TableService, and provides it to an untrusted or semi-trusted application.
trans-unit.target: A trusted application such as a cloud-based service generates a SAS using the generateSharedAccessSignature of the TableService, and provides it to an untrusted or semi-trusted application.

trans-unit.source: For example, a mobile app.
trans-unit.target: For example, a mobile app.

trans-unit.source: The SAS is generated using a policy, which describes the start and end dates during which the SAS is valid, as well as the access level granted to the SAS holder.
trans-unit.target: The SAS is generated using a policy, which describes the start and end dates during which the SAS is valid, as well as the access level granted to the SAS holder.

trans-unit.source: The following example generates a new shared access policy that will allow the SAS holder to query ('r') the table, and expires 100 minutes after the time it is created.
trans-unit.target: The following example generates a new shared access policy that will allow the SAS holder to query ('r') the table, and expires 100 minutes after the time it is created.

trans-unit.source: Note that the host information must be provided also, as it is required when the SAS holder attempts to access the table.
trans-unit.target: Note that the host information must be provided also, as it is required when the SAS holder attempts to access the table.

trans-unit.source: The client application then uses the SAS with TableServiceWithSAS to perform operations against the table.
trans-unit.target: The client application then uses the SAS with TableServiceWithSAS to perform operations against the table.

trans-unit.source: The following example connects to the table and performs a query.
trans-unit.target: The following example connects to the table and performs a query.

trans-unit.source: Since the SAS was generated with only query access, if an attempt were made to insert, update, or delete entities, an error would be returned.
trans-unit.target: Since the SAS was generated with only query access, if an attempt were made to insert, update, or delete entities, an error would be returned.

trans-unit.source: You can also use an Access Control List (ACL) to set the access policy for a SAS.
trans-unit.target: You can also use an Access Control List (ACL) to set the access policy for a SAS.

trans-unit.source: This is useful if you wish to allow multiple clients to access the table, but provide different access policies for each client.
trans-unit.target: This is useful if you wish to allow multiple clients to access the table, but provide different access policies for each client.

trans-unit.source: An ACL is implemented using an array of access policies, with an ID associated with each policy.
trans-unit.target: An ACL is implemented using an array of access policies, with an ID associated with each policy.

trans-unit.source: The following example defines two policies; one for 'user1' and one for 'user2':
trans-unit.target: The following example defines two policies; one for 'user1' and one for 'user2':

trans-unit.source: The following example gets the current ACL for the hometasks table, then adds the new policies using setTableAcl.
trans-unit.target: The following example gets the current ACL for the hometasks table, then adds the new policies using setTableAcl.

trans-unit.source: This approach allows:
trans-unit.target: This approach allows:

trans-unit.source: Once the ACL has been set, you can then create a SAS based on the ID for a policy.
trans-unit.target: Once the ACL has been set, you can then create a SAS based on the ID for a policy.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a new SAS for 'user2':
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a new SAS for 'user2':

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of table storage, follow these links to learn how to do more complex storage tasks.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of table storage, follow these links to learn how to do more complex storage tasks.
